2020 Spacestation

CURRENT SHIPS:

TIANGONG-1 (SPACESTATION)

SHENGZHOU (ORBITAL MANNED CRAFT)

LONG MARCH ROCKET (LAUNCHER)

TIANGONG-2 (SPACESTATION)

2020 STATION PROTOTYPE (SPACESTATION)

UPCOMING

CHANG'E PROBE FAMILY (SAMPLE RETURN PROBES, ROVERS, AND MUNAR LANDERS)

CHINESE 2020 STATION MODULES (SPACESTATION)

TIANGONG-1

The Tiangong-1 is a spacestation launched by the CNSA in 2011, and is scheduled to be deorbited in 2014 or late 2013. The Tiangong-1 has only one docking port. There will be a link coming with a launcher soon (I'm smoothing out the issues with my version of the Long March), but the simple payload version will always be up (So feel free to tie it to several NERVA's and send it to the 'red' Planet...gettit?). I really don't know how many times I have rebuilt this. Probably near the dozenth mark (I go to Mulblins page, and I'm like "Hmmmm....THATS NOT GOOD ENOUGH! REBUILD IT!") Comes with basic science equipment (Pre-0.22 Science Gear). Basic statistics.

WEIGHT: 25.8 tonnes.

PART COUNT: 208 (I don't even know what type of stuff Jeb put inside the habitats. Don't ask.)

ELECTRIC CHARGE: 8135

FUEL: 1170

OXIDIZER: 1430

XENON GAS (I don't even know): 700

CREW: 4

Javascript is disabled. View full album

(DOES NOT COME WITH LAUNCHER) LINK------> https://www./?mflp4nq6hfoaxjn <-------LINK (DOES NOT COME WITH LAUNCHER)

SHENGZHOU SPACECRAFT

The Shengzhou is a reliable spacecraft, composed of three modules. A crew capsule (That seats up to two), a service module, and a docking module/orbital operations module. The Shengzhou Spacecraft is docked with the Tiagong Spacestation. And no, I most definately assure you that is not, in any form or shape, a ripoff of the Soyuz. Nope. Na da. There are two versions, one that comes with a launcher, and one that does not. The Long March Rocket can be a little tricky to handle, and the fairing seperation can be a little messy and create debris (Don't worry, the Shengzhou craft can survive many bumps and scartches with nearby objects in case the fairing strikes you) but it has tons of dV and can put the Shengzhou onto a circummunar trajectory, a geosynchorus orbit, or a escape trajectory (From Kerbin).

SHENGZHOU ONLY

WEIGHT: 4.46 Tonnes

PART COUNT: 29

FUEL: 100 (Only 90 are usable)

ELECTRIC CHARGE: 110

CREW: Currently holds two. I am working on a variant that hodls three. Since it's in two different capsules clipping each other, you will have to use the "Crew" tab to fill it to capacity (I truly apologize for any inconvience this has caused you, as well as any distress from boredom and isolation from the Kerbalnauts you sent to the Tiagong/Other Stations)

Javascript is disabled. View full album

TIANGONG-2

A Tiangong-1 with the ability to dock more than two spacecraft. Kinda a lame upgrade, but who cares? A little less heavier and less part count.

WEIGHT: 24.5 tonnes.

PART COUNT: 204 (I don't even know what type of stuff Jeb put inside the habitats. Don't ask.)

ELECTRIC CHARGE: 8135

FUEL: 1170

OXIDIZER: 1430

XENON GAS (I don't even know): 700

CREW: 4

(NO LAUNCHER YET) LINK--------> https://www./?e8j4epbysvpwnl7 <--------- LINK (NO LAUNCHER)

Edited November 26, 2013 by NASAFanboy

Almost done with Long March, working on the 2020 Spacestation and the Chang'e probes. Also will work on redesign of Tiangong and Shengzhou.

All I need to do now is to perfect the payload fairings for Long March.

Edited November 25, 2013 by NASAFanboy
Working with 2020 Spacestation, I really want to get the pics of the experience, models, working condition.

Finished the Long March.

Now to work on my true passion, the Chiniese Spacestation!

Here is a teaser of the partly completed station.

EDIT: Here is a picture of the fully-completed prototype.

Edited November 25, 2013 by NASAFanboy

WIll upload 2020 spacestation and Chang'e tommorrow. I've changed the layout and the modules of the station alot, the teaser you saw doesn't closely represent the finished product at all. As of now, I'm struggling to keep part count down, as I'm trying to make my crafts so you can casually surf the internet while you wait for your module to achieve orbit or something, without suffering horrendus lag. And yes, I do surf the internet while flying my ships.

Should I give out the station in pieces and leave it up to you guys to disassemble/launch it in pieces, or give it out whole and link you to hyperedit (A god-mode that lets you throw things into orbit without launching them).

Oh, and just a quick personal reminder.

I really have to start working on the Long March Variants for the Tiangong....

Edited November 26, 2013 by NASAFanboy

CHINESE 2020 SPACESTATION MODULES

This is a monster. At mroe than 1000 parts, it even has a .craft file size of 1.2 MB, and has nearly destroyed my computer. The station comes with a fully-functioning Shengzhou spacecraft and a Tiangong cargo ship. The station will require hyperedit to get into orbit, and I plan on releasing seperate modules soon. Not flexible. The station panels do not move (They are OX-STAT panels superglued to large metal panels, after all). I'm only going to include a picture of the station core...my computer cannot handle the rest.

PART COUNT: 1117 Parts

WEIGHT: 92-95 tonnes

ELECTRIC CHARGE: 28450

XENON GAS: 700

FUEL: 2035

(HYPEREDIT, MORE RAM REQUIRED) LINK ------> https://www./?dleubytjrpqdhyl <----- LINK

Someone with a good computer, please send me a picture of the station. Time to work on the launchers and Chang'E probes and a hypothetical "Mars Dragon" mission (A chinese manned mission to Mars)

Edited November 26, 2013 by NASAFanboy
Subscribed. I would love to see a 0.24 Long March 5 and Long March 9 rocket.
Your lucky there isn't a rule for to awesome, nice work man.
